Yes; it is a shop consisting of two front windows - it was a parlour originally, but is converted into a shop - there is no shop window - goods are in the window - there is no name over the door - the door which leads to the shop is open by day - the street door is not shut, it many be occasionally - I swear there are goods in the window, and have been for years - there is a counter - the things in the window can be seen outside - I place sometimes ribbons, sometimes handkerchiefs and flannel in the windows - the door is not open at night, to my knowledge - if it is, it is not with my permission - the outer door is left open during the day for customers to come into the shop - I have got no light in the passage.

Q. You sold fourteen yards of the silk - what became of the rest? A. It was packed up and taken to Mr. Hart - I make no entry of what I sell - I keep an invoice book for all goods which I buy - I do not keep an account of sales - Mrs. Samuels was by when I sold it.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Whether you keep an entry or not, are you sure the silk you got from Lazarus was the same silk you gave up to Mr. Hart? A. It was.
JOSEPH LAZARUS re-examined. Q. Did you represent to Samuel that the silks came out of pledge? A. I told him the party who sold it to me told me it came out of pledge, which the prisoner did.

ABRAHAM HART
. I had a brown paper parcel, which I gave to Vann, the police-officer - my father desired me to take it to the office.
JOSEPH SAMUEL re-examined. Mr. Hart called at my house to inquire after the silk, and produced the patterns, and said, "Have you any like this?" - I said, "Yes," here it is, and gave it to him.

THOMAS VANN
. I am a constable of Worship-street.Mr. Westmacott has the parcel, I received it, and delivered it to Mr. Moore - here are six yards and a half of green, and thirty-two and a quarter of black - the house is in the parish of Christchurch, Spitalfields.

THOMAS WESTMACOTT
. I superintend Mr. Moore's silk manufactory - I produce the silk which I got from Vann - it is worth 4s. 6d. a yard - when taken from the loom it would be in a rough state, but the value of the material by the weight and quality is 4s. 6d.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Look at the green silk, if that was in a state for sale, what would it be sold at per yard to the public? A. 5s.

Q. Is 2s. 9d. any thing like a fair price? A. It depends on the condition it is in - I should not like to send it out of our establishment in that state - any dealer that understands his business, would see that is not fit for sale.

ELKAN HYMAN re-examined. This black silk is mine - I know it by the general appearance of the work, and I have a particular mark to the selvidge - it is the same quality of silk as that taken out of our loom.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do not you have that particular mark on all the silk you work on? A. No- it was through a mistake made in the entering.

LEVIEN MORRIS re-examined. This green silk is the same quality as that taken from my loom - I know the work by the general appearance - I can tell my own work- it corresponds with what was left behind.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is it the same silk as you went before the magistrate about, and charged the boy with stealing? A. Of course.
THOMAS WESTMACOTT re-examined. I believe this to be my master's silk - there is a general appearance about the silk the witnesses manufacture.
Witness for the Defence.

EDWARD PORTER
. I am a linen-draper, and live in Regent-place, Globe-road, Mile-end. I have known the prisoner between three and four years - on Monday, the 2nd or 3rd of March I went with him to Hitchin, in Hertfordshire - we slept there on Monday evening, attended the market on Tuesday, and left Hitchin on Tuesday evening - we went to Dunstable, slept there on Tuesday, attended the market onWednesday, slept there Wednesday and Thursday nights, and left on Friday morning for St. Alban's - slept there Saturday and Sunday, and returned to town on Monday - I swear we were not out of each other's company six hours during the whole time, taking, one half-hour and another half-hour together - Hitchin is thirty-three or thirty-four miles from London.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You came home on the 9th? A. We came home on Monday, the 9th of 10th - yes, I can tell, for my birth-day was on the 7th - that was on Friday- I remember now from that particular circumstance - I have known Mr. Nathan, having seen him at his brother's often - I am not particularly intimate with him - we did not sleep in the same room together - we had never gone journeys together before, nor since - there was no companion with us; but we met an individual whom we both knew, both at Hitchin and Dunstable - I gave my testimony to the solicitor in this case - I did not give him the name of any individual who I met - I believe I saw Nathan again on Wednesday, the 12th, at his house, No. 6, Greenfield-street, Whitechapel-road - I went to him on business - he sells handkerchiefs - I never saw him sell silks - we took silk handkerchiefs, ribbons, and lace down with us - he did not deal in silk - he was a general dealer - he has not shop- there is a room you may call a shop, but it is a private house - things hang up in the window - I never saw silks there - I never saw him since this Wednesday that I know of- I may have seen him, but have forgotten it - I have been at his brother's many times - I cannot tell whether on any of those times I have seen him - I may have seen him - I cannot swear whether I have seen him at his brother's since or not - I saw him on the 12th at his own house - I cannot swear that he has been out of the way, but I have heard that he has been in the country - I had been at his house I think about a week before I took the journey with him - I never went to his house before that once - it was at his brother's that we made up our journey together - his brother is here - I had seen him at his brother's about a month before we made up the journey, or it might have been a week - I cannot tell whether his brother was present- some individuals were present - I cannot tell who - if I recollect correctly, one of Henry Nathan's sons was present - I know somebody was present, and one of the sons, but which I cannot swear - some of the sons are invariably in the shop - it was in the shop we made up the journey - there was not half a dozen people present - there might have been customers in the shop - we intended to be out in the country for a month, but the prisoner, at the time he was staying at St. Alban's, was rather queer in the head - I persuaded him to return home - I cannot swear whether his brother was present when I agreed to travel with him- it was between nine and two o'clock that we made the agreement - I have been in the habit of going to his house four or five times a week, and cannot speak to the hour more correctly - we slept at the Red Lion at St. Alban's - I think the landlord's name is Dalton or Salton - we slept up stairs in the first pair - the Red Lion is at the corner of the road leading to Dunstable - I think we slept at the Black Horse at Dunstable - the landlord's name is Holmes- I did not give his name to the solicitor, for I was not asked - I never knew of this till last Saturday - I do not know but somebody may be here who saw us in the country.
MR. CLARKSON. A. Are you quite sure that from Monday the 3d to the 10th, he was travelling with you to Hitchin and other places? A. Yes.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Life .
See page 554.

1087.
ANN WELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d. of July , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 sovereign; 3 sixpences; and 2 half-pence; the goods and monies of
Azariah Lloyd
, from his person .

AZARIAH LLOYD. I live in Shepherd-street, Golden-square. On the 3d of July I had been drinking rather freely with my friends, in Jermyn-street, at the Harp Tavern- I left there about a quarter before one o'clock in the morning- I went up the Haymarket
, to return home - the prisoner accosted me, and walked with me up Windmill-street - I was very much intoxicated, and know nothing further than that I missed my watch, and met a policeman - the property was found on the prisoner - I have no recollection of what passed.

HENRY LOWMAN
(police-constable C 60). I apprehended the prisoner in Regent-street; she was not with the prosecutor - I had received information from him, and took her from his description, having seen her in the street - I said, "Have you got that man's watch?" - she said, "Yes, I have"- I said, "Give it me" - she said, "I will not" - I took a bag out of her hand, and on opening it, at the station-house, I found the watch - she said he had given it to her - I also found a sovereign, three sixpences, and two half-pence on her - the prosecutor was asked if he had lost any money - he put his hand into his pocket, and said he had lost a sovereign, and, he thought, about half-a-crown - the prisoner, said, he gave her the watch, but a gentleman gave her the money.

A. LLOYD re-examined. I am satisfied I could not have given her the watch, because I would not part with it for 5l. - I missed it directly I parted, from her - I will swear I did not give it her - I kept my money in my left hand pocket - I can undertake to say, I did not give her the money - I know what money I had when I left the tavern; and missing my watch rather sobered me; I directly complained to the policeman.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you give me the watch, and say, "Come up here with me, I have no money to give you, here is my watch?" A. I do not believe I did - I will swear I did not.
H. LOWMAN re-examined. She told me she had got the watch directly I asked her, and at the station-house she said he gave it to her - here is a half-penny, with five holes in it, I found on her.
A. LLOYD re-examined. I can swear to that half-penny and sixpence.
NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1088.
ISAAC THOMAS WELSHMAN
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury .
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. Tuesday, July 8, 1834.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1089.
JAMES CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June
, 1 coat, value 2l. 10. , the goods of
James Kemp
, and
EDWARD GREENWOOD
for
feloniously receiving the same , against the Statute.

JAMES KEMP. I live in Cleveland-street, Marylebone
- I am a licensed retailer of beer - on the 25th of June, about one o'clock, I received information, and looked into my first-floor front room - the door was unlocked, and the key nearly pushed out - I had locked it - I missed my coat, which had been hanging behind my door - this is it - I had seen it safe ten minutes before.

CAROLINE BIRTLES
. I lodge with my father and mother at the prosecutor's - about one o'clock, I heard a knock at the door - I went and saw Chapman - he said he wanted a person in the second-floor front room - I said they did not live there then - he said never mind; the persons who lived there then would do - he went up - I told my mother, and we both looked out, and saw him go out with a bundle - he had no bundle when he came in.
Chapman. I had my tools in my apron. Witness. No, he had nothing.

MARY BIRTLES
. I am the witnesses's mother - I looked out of the window, and saw Chapman go out with a bundle in an apron under his arm - I followed him to Mr. Brickle's, the pawnbroker - I pushed the door open, and saw Chapman and another person who, I suppose, was Greenwood - I asked the pawnbroker if the coat was there - he said it was- I tried to seize Chapman, but he got from me - I went with the officer to his lodgings, and he was taken.

THOMAS HEALEY
. I am shopman to Mr. Brickle, a pawnbroker - about half-past one o'clock, the prisoners came with this coat - Greenwood asked 1l. on it - whilst I was looking at it, there was a cry, "He has stolen the coat" - Greenwood ran out - I ran to the door, and caught him - he broke from me, but the mob followed him - no one took any notice of Chapman, and he walked home, but I knew where he lived, and I sent and took him.
Chapman's Defence. I was in the habit of going to Mr. Cartwright, who used to live there - I had my tools in my apron.
Greenwood's Defence. I met Chapman - I went with him to several places, and he asked me to pawn the coat for him.

CHAPMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined One Year .

GREENWOOD -
NOT GUILTY .

1090.
ELIZABETH RUSSELL
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 27th of June , 5 pair of socks, value 1s. 3d; 2 pair of stockings, value 6d.; and 2 petticoats, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
Abraham Stillwell
, which had lately before been stolen ; against the Statute.

ELIZABETH STILLWELL
. I am the wife of Abraham Stillwell - we live in Little Ormond-yard - I sent my daughter to sell some rags once, but never to sell any socks, or stockings, or petticoats - I missed a great many articles at different times - these are some of them.

ELIZABETH STILLWELL, Jun. I am the prosecutrix's daughter - I took the all these articles to the prisoner's, at different times - I took them from my mother - I asked the prisoner if she would buy them; she said yes, and as many more as I pleased - she keeps a shop in Liquor Pond-street, and buys all sorts of things - I went there twelve or thirteen times - she gave me one penny a pair for these socks, and two-pence or three-pence a piece for these flannel petticoats.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How came you first to go to the woman's? A. My mother first sent me to sell some rags - I did not tell her that my mother had sent these socks, as they were very moth-eaten - the prisoner said they were moth-eaten - I said I knew it - I do not know why - the prisoner did not give me 2d. a pair for these socks, only 1d. - I am fourteen years old - my eldest brother is ten or eleven - he went to the prisoner's shop also - I do not know how he came to go there - I did not think whether I was doing any harm - I bought cakes with the money - I have not been to any other shop but the prisoner's to sell things - she lives nearly half-a-mile from my mother's - I do not know that there is such a shop as the prisoner's nearer to my mother's - my mother did not tell me what shop to go to, when I took the rags to sell.

WILLIAM BAKER ASHTON
(police-serjeant G 11). I went to the prisoner, and asked if she had ever bought any thing of this girl - she said, "No" - I found these things there, and took her to Hatton-garden - she then said she had bought some socks of this girl.
ELIZABETH STILLWELL. I had been to the prisoner's shop the day before, and saw a flannel-petticoat and a pincloth outside the door.

Cross-examined. Q. Were they not publicity exposed? A. Yes - the pin-cloth has been sold - I send my little boy out on errands - I do not know how he found his way to the prisoner's - I never sent him there, nor this girl either - these petticoats are worth 6d. or 1s. a-piece - I sent this girl to sell the rags about Christmas - I never sent the boy.

Prisoner's Defence. The girl said her mother had got several moths in the house, as her father was a smith, and her mother thought she had better dispose of them - I put them up for sale every day - I gave the girl 6d. or 8d. a-piece for the petticoats, and 2d. a pair for the socks.
NOT GUILTY .

1091.
JAMES WISE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 cart, value 10l. , the goods of
William Sawyer
.

WILLIAM SAWYER. I live in Pearson-street, Kingsland-road
. On the 28th of May, I had a cart in a shed - it was safe at half-past eight o'clock in the evening; and the next morning the staple of the gate was drawn, and the cart was gone - I received information, and went to Gosport - I saw my cart by the market-place there - I saw the prisoner there the next day - I had known him before as living in my neighbourhood - he said, "What are you up to?" - I said, "I am come after my cart" - he said, "Is that your cart? if I had known that, you should have had it, and the horse too" - my cart was worth 10l.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What day of theweek was the 28th of May when you saw it safe? A. On Wednesday, I believe - it was in a shed in Downham-row, about a furlong from my house - it may be about five miles from Vauxhall.

JOHN STROUD
. I am constable of Gosport. About the 6th of June, I saw the cart by the side of the market - I saw a description of it in the Hue-and-cry, and wrote a letter to London - I took the prisoner at the Northumberland Arms - I told him I wanted him respecting a cart that I suspected was stolen - he said if that was all, he bought it and paid for it, and gave 6l. 5s. for it - he said he bought it in London - I do not think he said of whom.

ROBERT AYMER
. I am a corn-dealer, and live at Gosport. I have known the prisoner about three months - he came to Gosport to me on Saturday evening, the 31st of May - he informed me he had left a horse and cart at my stable, and wished me to keep it till he had sold it - on the next morning he showed me the cart - it was the same that Sawyer saw - the prisoner said he had bought it for his son in London; but he had several others, and he should not want it; and he should sell the horse with it in a day or two - he asked me if I would buy it - I said it was too heavy for my work; I would not have it - he then asked me if I would allow my name to be chalked on it to be sold, and to inquire of me - I told him he might if he pleased; and it was put on - I was to ask 10l. for it.
Cross-examined. Q. There was nothing like concealment about it? A. No - it was a narrow-wheeled cart.

WILLIAM HOLLAND
(police-constable N 146). I went to Gosport, and took the prisoner - in coming to town he told me he bought the cart at the back of Bedlam; and in another part of the road, he said the bought it at Hoxton - on the 29th of May, when the cart was stolen, I was employed to trace it - I found the track of a wheel in a direction towards the prisoner's house in Hoxton - I have known him for years - I believe he was not there then.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it not a public road? A. Yes; but it had been newly gravelled - there were other tracks on it.
Witness for the Defence.

JOHN SHEARING
. I get my living by putting the penal statutes in force. On the 29th of May, I went into a public-house, near Vauxhall-gate, to have a pint of beer, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning - I saw the prisoner there - I have known him some years - he was sitting at a table with another man - I saw the prisoner give the man six sovereigns, and he went to the bar and came in again and put down two half-crowns on the table- they then shook hands, and the prisoner said, "Now it is my cart" - I saw a piece of paper on the table, and a pen and ink - I should not know the paper again - it was a similar paper to this one - I considered it to be a receipt.

COURT. Q. Where had you come from that morning? A. From my own house in the Borough - I was going down the Wandsworth-road to look after stage coaches - it was the first public-house on the right after you get through the Vauxhall-gate - there were two or three persons there - I did not see the landlord - I saw a female, whom I took to be the servant - the prisoner with the other men were sitting on the right-hand - I said to him, "Jemmy, there you are" - he said, "Very well" or "All right" - I did not go before the magistrate - the prisoner's son came to me on sunday morning last - I had no one with me at that time- I do not take a witness with me - I am the witness my - self - I was going to look after coaches, or any thing else - I do not know what change the prisoner went for, but he brought in two half-crowns, and put them on the table.
COURT to R. AYMER. Q. When you saw the cart at Gosport, what name was on it? A."George Porter, Hoxton, Middlesex, No. 2728," was on the plate.
WILLIAM SAWYER. There was no plate on it when I lost it - I had taken my board off to have it fresh painted.
NOT GUILTY .

1092.
SARAH WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 28 yards of cotton, value 8s. , the goods of
William Galliers
.

EDWARD PORTER
. I was in the service of Mr. William Galliers - he lives in Shoreditch
. On the 24th of June, I saw the prisoner and two other girls - I pursued them - the prisoner turned down a court, and I took her with this twenty-eight yards of print on her person - it is Mr. Galliers', and had been hanging on a rail at his door.
Prisoner. I had the print, but two young girls threw it on me - I was not near the shop. Witness. I saw her about the shop an hour before, and saw the other two girls speaking to her.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1093.
BENJAMIN GEORGE WEBB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 31b. of brass, value 6s. , the property of
John Clemmitt
and another.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

RICHARD HILL
. I have been employed about Messrs. Clemmitt and Bullock's premises - on the 19th of June, about a quarter-past eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner coming out of the booking-office with something long in his hand, wrapped up in paper.

JOHN BROMLEY
. I am a tinman and brazier, and live in Playhouse-yard, St. Luke's, and I am headborough of St. Luke's. On the 19th of June, the prisoner came to me about ten minutes before nine - he put this brass standard into my hand rolled up in paper - he said, "Will you buy this?" - he offered it for 2s. - I said I would not - he said he would throw it away - he went off, and I ran after him- he went to Gibson's foundry - I saw the policeman, and we went in and took the prisoner to the station-house - he said he had bought it in the Borough for 1s. - it is worth 14s. or 15s.

THOMAS PRINDEVILLE
(police-constable G 140). I took the prisoner - I asked him where he got the gas tube - he said he bought it for 1s. - I said that would not do, and took him to the station-house - he then said he picked it up - the next day he said he took the tube, and did not care what might happen to him - it was wrapped up in this posting-bill belonging to Mr. Clemmitt, and that led me there.
Prisoner. There was no bill round it - he asked me what I would give him to let me go - I said, nothing.

JOHN CLEMMITTS. I am proprietor of the Green Arbour-inn, Old Bailey
. I have one partner - I had two of these standards - they were fixed when I took the office - I took them down - I had one fixed in another part of the office, and the other was put on a shelf - it was similarto this, but I cannot swear to it - when the officer brought it, mine was missing from the shelf in the booking-office - this is one of the posting bills of my office - they were kept in a hole in the front office - I have left the prisoner in the office at times, but never entrusted him with this brass standard.

JOHN MAJOR
. I am a brass worker - I lacquered two gas standards for that office twice - to the best of my belief, these are the two - this is the one that was fixed, and this is the one produced by the officer - I fixed one up, and put the other on the shelf.
Prisoner's Defence. I have often been left in the office for hours together, and had to give those bills - I was hardly ever without some in my pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Confined Three Months .

1094.
SUSAN SMITH
was indicted for a
stealing, on the 30th of June
, 3 pails, value 3s.; 4 shoe brushes, value 1s.; 1 tin kettle, value 1s.; 1 tub, value 3d.; 2 towels, value 3d.; 1 pair of pattens, value 4d.; 1 paid of clogs, value 4d. ; the goods of
Bince Randall
.

MARTHA RANDALL
. I am the wife of Bince Randall - he is a carpenter , and lives at Hampstead
. On the 30th of June, I was sitting at breakfast up stairs, about eight o'clock in the morning - I heard a noise, and went down - I saw the prisoner with my pails, and the other articles in her possession - I said she had got my pails - I took them out of her hand and put them in my room - she said they were hers - she had got them about 100 yards from my door - the officer came about two hours afterwards, and I gave him the things.
Prisoner. I am not the person who took the things - another woman gave them to me. Witness. I saw no one near her.
Prisoner's Defence. A person had taken a lodging with me - she said she had some things in different places - I went with her, and she gave me these things.
GUILTY . Aged 45.

1095. SUSAN SMITH was again indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June
, 1 kettle, value 2s.; 1 dish, value 6d.; 4 shoe-brushes, value 1s.; 1 pail, value 1s.; 3 shirts, value 2s.; 2 shifts, value 1s.; 1 sheet, value 6d.; 1 saucepan, value 6d.; 1 apron, value 2d.; 1 towel, value 2d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 2d. , the goods of
John Bennett
.

SARAH BENNETT
. I am the wife of John Bennett - we live at Hampstead
- I missed these articles on the 30th of June about seven o'clock; I was called by the officer to Church-lane, and saw them - they are mine.

MARY SMITH
. The prisoner came to my house, in Church-lane, about half-past seven o'clock, and asked me to permit her to leave these articles with me, as she had forgotten the key of her door - I told her to put them in the hall; they would be quite safe - about two hours after she came again, and said she was sorry to leave them so long, but her husband had taken the key to London, and she did not like to break open the door - I afterwards heard some - thing, and told the officer, who brought the prisoner to me- these are the articles.
Prisoner. I am not the person. Witness. I can take my oath she is - she said her husband was a silversmith in Soho-square.
Prisoner. The same person gave me these things.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined One Year .

1096.
WILLIAM STRIPLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 1 coral necklace, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Starke
, from the person of
Elizabeth Charlotte Starke
.

MARY ANN STARKE
. I am the wife of Thomas Starke- I sent my child out with Booth, on the 7th of June - she had four rows of beads on - she returned in half an hour without them.

SARAH BOOTH
. I took the child out to buy some watercresses and milk - I went to a milk shop in New Inn-yard
- I had the child, Elizabeth Charlotte Starke, in my arms - the prisoner followed me, and put his hands up to the child's neck, and took the necklace off - he ran - I pursued him, and cried, "Stop thief" - the officer took him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not see the beads in the prisoner's hand? A. No, I saw his hand up to her neck - there was no one else there, but a woman for some milk, and the person who sold the milk- the prisoner was taken in the Curtain-road; I suppose forty yards from the place.

RICHARD NURSE
(police-constable G 37). I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and pursued the prisoner - a great many people followed him - he ran to the Curtain-road, and was stopped - I have not found the beads.
NOT GUILTY .

1097.
HENRY SEAKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 handkerchief, value 9d., the goods of
Samuel Smith
, from his person .

SAMUEL SMITH. I lived at Mr. Isaac's lodging-house, in West-street, Smithfield; but have been obliged to leave there, in consequence of the prisoner's companions ill-using me - on Sunday, the 1st of June, I went into a cook-shop to get dinner - the prisoner followed me very closely - I felt my handkerchief, slide out of my pocket very gently - I turned to the prisoner, and he threw my handkerchief on the floor - this is it.

THOMAS JOSEPH AVIS
(police-constable C 39). I took the prisoner, and received the handkerchief from the prosecutor.
Prisoner's Defence. There were twenty people in the shop - I did not touch the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1098.
HENRY STONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of May , 1 shirt, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 8d.; 10 spoons, value 7s.; 1 cloak, value 1s. 6d.; 4 shillings, 4 sixpences, and two pence three farthings in copper monies , the goods and monies of
Samuel Hough
.

SAMUEL HOUGH. I am master of the Shoreditch National School
- on the morning of the 17th of May I was called by the police, a little after four o'clock, and went to the school-room - on opening the door, I saw the things in a confused state, and the back windows were open - I stayed at the door, while the officer went round and broughtthe prisoner - I gave him in charge - I missed some money from boxes in the school, and the property stated in the indictment - it is the property of the committee of the school, and was in my charge - the locks of the boxes had been forced open, and 4s. was found on the prisoner - he was quite a stranger.

CHARLES WILKINS
(police-constable N 79). I was on duty near the school about four o'clock in the morning of the 17th of May - I heard some person walking as it appeared without shoes - I peeped in, but could see no one - I called the master - he opened the door - I saw the things very much displaced - it appeared, that whoever had been there, had escaped by the back window - I went into George's-square, which is at the back of the school, and found the prisoner lying down behind a door in a garden - I took him, and asked what he wanted in the school - he said he was one of the scholars, and had stopped in all night - I found 4s. 2½d. on him, and this pincushion.

ELIZABETH PARISH
. I am one of the scholars - this pincushion is mine - I left it in my lap bag in the school the night before, at five o'clock - this shirt and these stockings are my governess's, and were in the closet in the committee-room - my box had been locked.

JOHN BLADES
. I saw the prisoner on the top of my wash-house - I asked what he did there - he said he was a scholar at Mr. Robert's school - that he had been kept back at night, and slept in the school-room, and if I would let him through, he would be obliged to me - he said he belonged to Mr. Stone, who is a neighbour of mine, and a respectable man - I let him through, and he was taken by the policeman.
Prisoner's Defence. My mother had turned me out the evening before - I went to this place to sleep, and when I heard the men coming, I got up, and Mr. Blades let me through his house.
NOT GUILTY .

1199.
ELIZABETH RICHMOND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of May , 6 towels, value 3s.; 2 pair of stockings, value 3s.; 3 yards, of lace, value 6s.; 1 pinafore, value 9d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1s.; 2 yards of dimity, value 6d.; 2 yards of linen, value 2s.; 1 cap, value 2s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 6d.; 1 shift, value 1s. 6d.; 1 nightgown, value 1s.; 1 bag, value 6d.; 12 yards of ribbon, value 4s.; 2 pair of socks, value 1s.; and 9 skeins of silk, value 6d. ; the goods of
James Veitch
.

JAMES VEITCH. I live at No. 16, Great Portland-street
, and am a hosier and glover . The prisoner was my servant - I missed things for a considerable time, and on the 22nd of May I gave the prisoner into custody - I told her it was for taking things from my house to a coal-shed - she said she had taken some, but they were of little value, and she would go and show us where they were - she went to the coal-shed with the officer, but found nothing there - she then denied all knowledge of them, and would tell nothing about them - these are my property - many of them have my mark on them - here are towels, lace, gloves, handkerchiefs, and a variety of other things.

ALICIA COOLINGS
. I live in Fitzroy-street, and keep a coal-shed - the prisoner used to buy articles of me - about a week or ten days before she brought these things, she told me she was going to leave her place in a few days, and as she expected some parcels from Scotland, she would be glad if I would let her leave them there - I said she might, and in about ten days she brought one sewed up, which appeared to have come a great way - she then brought a second parcel - and on the 22nd of May, she knocked me up a few minutes before six, and left another parcel - Hunter then came for the parcels, and I gave them to her.

ELLEN HUNTER
. I was passing, and the prisoner called me, and asked me to take the parcels to my place, which I did.

SAMUEL WAKEFIELD
(police-constable E 93). I took the prisoner, and got the goods from Hunter.
(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she had taken the things, fearing she should not receive her wages, as the prosecutor owed her 3l.)
JAMES VEITCH. The prisoner had been about ten weeks with me - she had not asked for any money.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined for Two Years .

1100.
FRANCIS FRANCIS
,
JOHN GISSON
, and
JOHN CHARLES
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 2 trusses of hay, value 4s. , the goods of
John Mills
.
MR. LEE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM JAMES BUDD
(police-constable S 123). On the 21st of June, at half-past two o'clock in the morning, I was on duty opposite Euston Mews - I heard something fall - I then heard some footsteps, and saw the prisoner Charles cross the mews with a truss of hay on his shoulders, which he took into Price's stables - I called Bugden - we went down the mews to Mr. Mills' stable, but in going down we found Price's stables open - when we got to Mr. Mills we saw the mark of two trusses of hay on the ground, under the window; one was dark, the other light, corresponding with the colour of the trusses we found - the prisoner Francis was at the loft window of Mr. Mills' stable - he said, "Good morning," and asked what brought us there so early - we then went to Price's stables, and found a truss of hay uncovered, and shortly after another partly covered over - I saw Charles in a corn bin - he appeared to be asleep - I asked him when the hay was brought in - he said in the night; and it was a hard thing his master could not have hay without our supposing it was stolen - I said, "Will you swear it did not come in within ten minutes?" - he said,"No" - I then said, "Where did you get it?" - he said, from the bottom of the mews, at No, 14" - I left him in custody, and went to Mr. Mills' stable - I knocked, and Francis put his head out - I told him to come down - he came down in his shirt - I told him to go up and put on his clothes, and I followed him - in going up I saw Gission on the stairs -Francis had passed him - I asked Gission what he did there- he said he had come to call the gentleman's servant - I said it was all stuff, and told him to go up stairs - we went up, and Francis asked Gisson what he did there - Gisson said,"To call you" - Francis said he had not given him any order - Gission said, "You know you told me," and Francis said, "I believe I did" - Gisson afterwards said he had come to borrow two trusses of hay - they were then taken; and Francis said, "We have got into trouble."

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you known Francis before this? A. Yes; he had been groom to Mr. Mills for five or six months - I have not heard him say that he had been in the habit of making loans of hay to the cabman's servant - Gisson said he came to borrow two trusses of hay - I know that persons who drive cabriolets come in at all hours - Gisson left his cabriolet on the stand, and came there.

THOMAS BOYCE
(police-constable S 159). I was called in - I recollect Gisson saying he had come to borrow two trusses of hay, and Francis said, "I have no knowledge of him."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you state before the magistrate that Francis said he had no knowledge of Gisson? A. Yes.

JOHN MILLS. I live at No. 14, Euston-square
; the stable belongs to me. I was shown the two trusses of hay, and on comparing them with what I had I believe it to be the same - I gave no authority to Francis, who is my groom , to part with any.

Cross-examined. Q. But I dare say it may have happened that you have lent and borrowed hay? A. I would lend it to any gentleman in the mews, but not to a cabman- I had desired Francis not to have any thing to do with these two men - he had given me satisfaction.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1101.
WILLIAM GEE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JOB ASHTON
. I live in Bridge-place, City-road-basin
- I have known the prisoner five or six years - I met him on the morning of the 29th of November last - he said he was very much distressed, and asked if I could employ him - I did, and sent him the next morning with two bushels of malt, and 8lbs. of hops - he never returned nor paid the money.

JAMES CHILD
. On the 30th of November , the prisoner brought me two bushels of malt, and 8lbs. of hops - he brought the bill of 26s., and my wife paid him.
GUILTY. Aged 36. - Recommended to mercy .
Confined for Three Months .

1102.
MARY BARNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 4 shirts, value 6s.; and 2 pair of trowsers, value 8s. , the goods of
Mary Webb
.

MARY WEBB. I am single . I do slop work - the prisoner lodged with me about four months - I received some trowsers and shirts to make for Mr. Allows - I made the trowsers, and the prisoner made the shirts - I am responsible for them all - on the 27th of May, she said she was going to take the shirts home to Mr. Allows, and I said she might.
Prisoner. You know we used to pawn the work every Saturday. Witness. Never in my life.

OLMENA ALLOWS
. I employed the prosecutrix to make these articles - the prisoner did not bring them home on the 27th of May - I got this one shirt at a pawnbroker's in the Commercial-road - I paid 9d. for it.
MARY WEBB. This is one of the shirts.

JAMES HENRY ANDREWS
(police-constable K 104). I took the prisoner - she was very much in liquor - I was about to search her - she said it was no use, for she had torn up the duplicates - this one shirt was found by going to different pawnbrokers.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined for Three Months .

1103.
GEORGE PERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Kirby
, from his person .

WILLIAM KIRBY. I am an embosser . On the 25th of June I was in the City-road
, about eleven or twelve o'clock in the forenoon - I was looking into a shop window, and, on turning, I saw two young men by my side - I suspected them, and felt for my handkerchief - it was not in my pocket- I looked in my hat, and it was not there - I went on, and they were before me - when they came to James-street, one of them, who was the prisoner, ran off - I pursued, and cried, "Stop thief!" - I picked up my handkerchief in the track he ran - I pursued him to Old-street, and he was taken - there was no one but the prisoner and I in the street, when I picket up my handkerchief.

THOMAS BILBOROUGH
(police-constable G 140). I took the prisoner - he said he got the handkerchief from another boy, but did not take it himself.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along, and a boy came by in great speed - I stepped into the road - a gentleman pursued me - I said, "There goes the lad" - he would not go after him, but took me.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1104.
ELIZABETH PINKERTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s.; 1 seal, value 6d.; and 1 key, value 6d., the goods of
John Burt
, from the person of
William Punchard
.

JOHN BURT. I am a seaman . I met William Punchard on the 10th of June, at the Ferry-house, in the Isle-of-dogs - I gave him my watch to take care of - I was going over to Greenwich - it was an old-fashioned silver watch, and the maker's name was Brown - it had a steel chain, a seal, and a key.

WILLIAM PUNCHARD. I received the watch, and as I was returning home that night, about half-past ten, I met the prisoner and another woman - they asked me to go with them - I went to a house in Limehouse-hole
- I went to an up-stairs room with both the women - I laid on the bed, and went to sleep - I had given them four shillings between the two - I awoke about two o'clock, and missed the watch which had been in my fob - I had pulled my jacket, off, but my trowsers were on - I opened the window, and sung-out for the police - the prisoner was gone - the other woman was there - she was taken, but discharged.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Your friend asked you to take care of his watch? A. Yes; I had been drinking a little when I went with the women; but I was not drunk - I had been in one public-house, and stayed about half-an-hour with a young man who is now just gone in to Sydney - after I left the public-house, I had to call at a doctor's - I had the watch safe then - that was about one hundred yards before I met the women - the prisoner laid on the bed; the other woman on the floor - I had been in the house about half an hour when I fell asleep.
COURT. Q. What sort of a stone was in the seal? A. A red stone, with "M. B.," in old English letters.

THOMAS SIZER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Shadwell. On the 11th of June, about half-past seven in the morning, the prisoner came to me and brought a watch - I advanced her 1l. on it - it was an old-fashioned silver watch, and had a steel chain, a seal and key - the maker's name was Brown - there was a red stone in the seal, with the initials"M. B." on it - it was redeemed the same evening by another person.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. No - she was in the shop about five minutes - we have a great many persons come there - I took notice enough of the prisoner to swear to her.

MARTIN COPELAND
. I took the prisoner - I taxed her with stealing the watch - she denied it.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the watch, nor the pawnbroker, till I was at Worship-street.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1105.
SAMUEL MASON
and
CHRISTOPHER JARVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 2 seals, value 10s.; 1 key, value 2s.; 1 ring, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; and 1 swivel, value 6d.; the goods of
John Lazarus Gray
, from his person .

JOHN LAZARUS GRAY. I am a cheesemonger . I was at the licensed victuallers' dinner, at the Mermaid, at Hackney
, on the 26th of June - I went into the garden, and fell asleep - it was then one o'clock in the morning of the 27th- I was tired, but not in liquor - I suppose I slept three-quarters of an hour - when I awoke, the officer came to me and asked if I had lost any thing - I said, "No;" but I felt, and missed my two seals, ring, ribbon, and key, and my handkerchief - when I felt myself rather sleepy, I put my handkerchief in my trowsers pocket, and kept my hand on it - I had not noticed the prisoners there - I saw them searched - I cannot say whose pocket the ribbon and seals came out of; but the handkerchief came out of Jarvis's pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. What time did you dine? A. It might be six o'clock; but I do not know exactly - I eat but very little, and very likely what I drank took the greater effect on me - I put my handkerchief in my pocket, not by the side - my watch did not come out - I could not get it out, the ring broke.

JOHN BEDFORD
. I am an inspector of police. I was on duty - I saw the prosecutor asleep, and Mason was calling him to awake - I placed myself in a situation where I could see what transpired - I saw the seals hanging from the prosecutor's watch fob - I soon after saw Mason leave the prosecutor, and go some distance between the tables and join Jarvis, who was sitting alone smoking his pipe - Mason then went again and sat by the prosecutor - he did so a second time - he then went to him a third time - I then went up and collared him and Jarvis - I took them to the prosecutor, and awoke him up - his seals were gone then - I asked him if he had lost any thing - he said, "No," but he felt, and missed his seals and ribbon - I took the prisoners to the station-house, and in Jarvis's right hand pocket I found the ribbon and seals; and in his small-clothes I found the handkerchief - I went in the morning to the gardens, and under the seat I found the swivel of the watch - there was nothing found on Mason - Jarvis was sitting the length of this Court from the prosecutor - I saw Mason join him three times, and leave him.

Cross-examined. Q. Were there other persons in the gardens? A. Yes, smoking their pipes; but not at that place - a person sitting where Janvis was, could see the prosecutor - it was in a straight line, and no one was between them - Jarvis did not attempt to interfere at all - Jarvis said he had been drawn into it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Mason's Defence. I never saw my fellow-prisoner till he was taken.
(Mr. Jackson, of the Peacock, Trinity-lane, in whose employ Mason was, gave him a good character.)

MASON -
GUILTY . - Aged 19.

JARVIS -
GUILTY . - Aged 35.
Confined for Six Months .

1106.
JANE LANE
and
CHARLOTTE KINSMAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 9 blankets, value 30s.; 3 urn rugs, value 3s.; 2 tea-pot rugs, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 candlestick, value 1s.; 1 milk-pot, value 15s.; 4 remnants of carpeting, value 12s.; 1 snuff-box, value 4s.; 1 parasol, value 2s.; 1 toilet bottle, value 3s.; 8 table mats, value 3s.; 1 coal-scuttle, value 7s.; 1 sugar basin, value 1s. 6d.; 1 tea-caddy, value 2s.; 1 tray, value 2s.; 2 petticoats, value 2s.; 1 gown, value 1s.; 6d.; 2 clocks, value 30s.; 1 tea-kettle, value 5s.; 1 umbrella, value 5s.; 1 chair, value 6s.; 1 compass, value 2s.; 3 bed-gowns, value 1s. 6d.; 6 pair of stockings, value 6s.; 1 hat, value 4s.; 18 handkerchiefs, value 12s.; 9 gowns, value 12s.; 4 coats, value 40s.; 7 pair of trowsers, value 30s.; 5 waistcoats, value 12s.; 8 towels, value 4s.; 4 pair of boots, value 10s.; 5 table-cloths, value 30s.; 68 knives, value 15s.; 68 forks, value 15s.; 13 spoons, value 4l.; and 3 labels, value 1s. ; the goods of
William Preston
.

WILLIAM PERSTON. I am now out of business - I lived at Limehouse; but the apartments I last occupied were at No. 3, Sutton-street - I had the first floor there - all this property was in my apartments - the prisoner Lane's husband occupied the house - I took the rooms of her - Kinsman appeared to me to be a char-woman , but instead of being there once of twice a week, she was there lately every day - I took the apartments in October, 1833, and in November I missed three new shirts - I asked Mrs. Lane about them - she said she supposed they had not been sent- on a Monday morning afterwards I was arranging my linen, and missed two more shirts - I asked Mrs. Lane about them - she said she could not tell, there had been no one there but the char-woman to clean the room, and she would send to her - I afterwards missed a pair of trowsers- on the 12th of June last, my daughter came to breakfast - I had a chest of drawers there, of which my daughter had the key - I had seen no change in them, but my daughter said they had been opened - I then saw Lane, and my daughter said to her, "Mrs. Lane, how is this? the drawers have been opened, and my things are gone." Lane fell on her knees, put her arms round her clothes, and said,"It is me, Miss, it is distress has driven me to do it; they shall be made right in a few days." My daughter thensaid, "Are my father's things safe?" - she said, "They are not all there." I missed a variety of articles, to the amount of 50l. - some of them are here.

CLEMENTIA STRINGER WALTON PRESTON
. I am the prosecutor's daughter - I had been away some time - I left my drawers all locked - when I returned, I found they had been rifled, and considerable property gone - I spoke to Lane - she said what my father has stated.

JAMES WHITE
(police-constable, K 285). I was sent for to Sutton-street, Commercial-road
- I found Lane, the prosecutor, and his daughter - he desired me to take charge of her for stealing property to a large amount - I asked what had become of it, and Lane gave me forty duplicates - I took her to the station-house, and searched her, but found nothing else - the next morning I went to the cell, and she gave me seventy more duplicates - I then searched her more closely, and found another pinned up in her bosom - I went the same evening to Red Lion-passage, Spitalfields, where I found Kinsman in a room with her two daughters - I asked her if she had any duplicates relating to Mr. Preston - she denied it three times - I said,"You will have no objection to my searching?" - she then said she would go and get them - I went with her to Elder-street, Shoreditch, and she took a bag in which I found 111 duplicates, out of which Mr. Preston identified 17 - two of them Lane said she gave to her, the rest she knew nothing about.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. I understand she gave you every facility? A. After I had taxed her with it she did - I believe there were seventeen duplicates which related to Mr. Preston's property, and the others to her own property.

THOMAS HAMES
(police-constable K 211). When the prisoner Lane was in the cell, she called to me, and gave me these two spoons, which were in an old handkerchief - she said, "These will make up the complement of Mr. Preston's which are lost."

THOMAS VESPER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a great variety of articles pawned by the two prisoners at different times - Mr. Preston identified the whole at my house - the prisoners sometimes came singly, and sometimes together.

WILLIAM HUMPHRYS
. I am shopman to Mr. Folkard, a pawnbroker, in the Commercial-road. I produce a great many articles which relate to this indictment - the greater part were pawned by Kinsman, some by Lane, and some by another female.
MR. PRESTON. These are all my property.

Cross-examined. Q. Lane is married? A. Yes. for any thing I know - I did not see her husband when I first went, but he made his appearance some time afterwards - he was living there nearly the whole time - he left this country just before this discovery took place - I think on the Sunday before - he came out of his room and took leave of me - he said he was going off with the Coldstream to the East Indies - I have no reason to doubt that they were man and wife - Kinsman used to come and work there- I do not know whether Lane sent her out to pawn things- Lane said before the magistrate, that Kinsman knew nothing of it.
COURT. Q. How often was Kinsman there for the last four or five months? A. Almost every day - she generally waited on me, and cleaned the room - she must have known the property was mine.
Lane's Defence. Among those articles there is a gold pin of my husband's, which has been in his possession for years - what I have done, I have owned to - the other prisoner is innocent.

(
James Roper
, broker, of Charlotte-street, Whitechapel, and Mr. Cressal, a cabinet-maker, gave Kinsman a good character.)

LANE -
GUILTY . Aged 45.

KINSMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against Kinsman.

1107.
JOHN KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 till, value 1s.; 2 shillings; 1 sixpence; and 2 pence in copper monies , the goods and monies of
Benjamin Battsort
.

SARAH BATTSON
. I am the wife of Benjamin Battson- we keep a baker's shop at Stoke Newington
. On the 25th of June, I was in the sitting-room, and saw the prisoner in the shop behind the counter - I ran to the door - the prisoner came from behind the counter, and dropped the till on the step of the door - this is it - it had 2s. 8d. in it - the prisoner ran off - I called my next door neighbour, and he was pursued and taken.

DANIEL BLAKELY
. On the evening of the 25th of June I was sitting inside my door - I heard a noise and went out- I saw the prisoner proceeding from the prosecutor's - I pursued, and took him.
GUILTY. Aged 17. - Recommended to mercy .
Confined Six Weeks .

1108.
MARY KEYS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 bag, value 1s.; 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 half-crown, 12 shillings, and 3 sixpences, the goods and monies of
Maria Susan Quantin
, her mistress .

MARIA SUSAN QUANTIN. I am a widow . The prisoner was my servant - she came for a month on trial, but finding at the end of five days that she did not suit me, I wished to part with her - I was about to discharge her on the 10th of June - I laid my bag on the table in the back kitchen where she was; it contained my purse and 16s. - I missed the bag, and the prisoner was gone to the water-closet - I went there, and heard the sound of money - I sent for the officer - he went to the water-closet and drew up this purse- the bag has not been found - I suppose she threw that down first.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did she not suggest your sending for an officer? A. Yes; I had not liked her conduct and she was impertinent - she had no money when she came to me, for I wanted a penny the next day - I keep a lodging-house.

FRANCIS ATKINS
(police-constable S 101). I was sent for - the prosecutrix said she was about to discharge the prisoner, and had missed her bag - the prisoner then went to the water-closet - I did not go there with her, but I got a light and went afterwards - I got the tongs, and found this purse - it had no money in it - I found 16s. on her.

ANNE HARCOURT
. I was there and saw the bag on the table - I saw the prisoner go to the corner of the table, where the bag was - it was then missed, and the prisonerwent to the water-closet - I went there with the prosecutrix, and heard something rattle - the officer found 16s. on the prisoner, in her pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the purse, or the money.
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1109.
ELLEN CALLAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , 2 gowns, value 5l.; 1 pair of stockings, value 2s.; 1 habit shirt, value 2s.; and 1 bonnet, value 10s. ; the goods of
Amelia Seymour
.

AMELIA SEYMOUR. I am single , and live in John-street, Waterloo-road
. The prisoner was in my service for one week - she left me without notice, on the morning of the 26th of April, before I was up - I heard nothing of her for a month, till she was found by the officer with some of my property.

REUBEN BEADLE
(police-constable G 75). I apprehended the prisoner on the 25th of May.

THOMAS CLARK
(police-constable G 88). I found this blue dress at the prisoner's lodgings, in Gardner's-lane, Westminster.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How do you know it was her lodging? A. I inquired at the house, and they showed me into the room.
AMELIA SEYMOUR. I saw this green dress, this hat, and habit shirt, and stockings on her at the office - this blue dress found at Westminster is mine.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you are in the habit of going to the theatre? A. No; I have a little private property, and let lodgings - I do not see gentlemen - I keep the house, No. 6, John-street, Waterloo-road - I have a gentleman and a lady lodge there - I do not remember a gentleman calling on me, and the prisoner being sent for a bottle of wine - my back parlour is a bed-room - I am sure the gentleman and I were not in that room - the prisoner was not asked to take a glass of wine - she never gave me any money - I lent her money to get decent things.

Prisoner. I paid her 6l. or 7l. - she lent me these dresses to go out and get gentlemen. Witness. It is quite false, she took property to the amount of 16l. - I gave her 2s. a week, and maintained her - I lent her 3s.(
Jane Jones
, wife of a cow-keeper, and
Ann Wilson
, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Six Months .

1110.
JAMES GLASS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 1 saw, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Brooks
.

WILLIAM STRACHAN
. I am in the employ of Mr. Thomas Brooks, cheesemonger , Shoreditch
- I had this saw on the counter, on the 31st of May - the prisoner was in the shop - I missed the saw, and stopped him, and he placed it on the counter.
(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had gone to the shop for some bacon, and had merely taken up the saw to examine it.)
WILLIAM STRACHAN. He did not ask for any thing.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1111.
ELIZA HEALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 3 blankets, value 4s.; 1 pair of pillow-cases, value 6d.; 1 pair of sheets, value 3s.; 2 pillows, value 5s.; 1 bolster, value 6d.; 1 yard of green baize, value 1s.; 1 tea-tray, value 2s.; 1 pair of bellows, value 1s. 6d.; 1 hearth-rug, value 7s.; 1 fender, value 10s.; and 1 looking-glass, value 2s. , the goods of
Benjamin Astwick
.

SARAH ASTWICK
. I am the wife of Benjamin Astwick, and live in Popham-street, Islington
. On the 12th of March I let the prisoner a first-floor front room - the property stated was in that room - she lived there with a man - they were to pay me 4s. 6d. a week - they paid me all but one week - on the 13th of June I went into their room, as they were fighting, and crying "Murder" - I then missed this property - the officer found the duplicates in the drawers in their room.

CHARLES HANES
(police-constable N 75). I found the duplicates, which led to the pawnbrokers.

WILLIAM WEST
. I am a pawnbroker - I have a fender, a hearth-rug, and six other articles, pawned by the prisoner.

GEORGE BARBER
. I am a pawnbroker - I have two blankets, pawned on the 12th of March, by the prisoner.

JOSEPH WOLSTENHOLME
. I am a pawnbroker - I have two pillows, pawned in the name of Mary Healey - I do not know by whom.

FREDERICK GILES
. I am a pawnbroker - I have a blanket pawned at our shop - I cannot say by whom.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor gave me leave to do any thing I liked in the room, so long as I kept my payments good.
SARAH ASTWICK. I never did - it is quite false.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Six Months .

1112.
WILLIAM KELLY
and
CHARLES KELLY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2d., the goods of
Samuel Shervill
.

SAMUEL SHERVILL. I was in Shoreditch
on Saturday, the 21st of June, and my pocket was picked - I do not know by whom; but I lost my handkerchief.

THOMAS TOOLE
. I am a boot and shoe-maker - I was in Shoreditch on the 21st of June - I saw the prosecutor and the two prisoners - they tried his pockets once or twice - he then crossed over to Church-street, and went into a wine vaults - they waited till he came out, and he went down New Inn-yard - they followed him; and Charles Kelly took the handkerchief out of his pocket - I told him, and we followed, but could not find him - the next night, I saw Charles Kelly, and had him taken - they were both together when the handkerchief was stolen.

Cross-examined by Mr. CHURCHILL. Q. Is this your first case this session? A. Yes; I was here last session in a case of one of the swell mob, for taking a gentleman's watch - I was the only person who saw it done - I do not know how often I have been here as a witness against boys, for robbing persons unknown - I have never been turned out of Court - I never was refused my expenses - I may have gone away without them.

Q. Will you swear you have not been refused your expenses here? A. I never was but once - I will swear I have not twice - I have gone away once or twice without them - I do not recollect having a case of two boys before Mr. Common Sergeant Denman - I was not turned out ofCourt, unless the witnesses were ordered out - I was not turned out after the case was over.

Q. Do you remember last Session being reminded of a case in a Session before, and swearing to Mr. Phillips that he bullied you out of it? A. I used those words, or something to that effect - I cannot recollect whether Mr. Lee had been counsel in that case.

TIMOTHY RYAN
(police-constable G 153). I took the prisoner from the information of the last witness.
Witness for the Defence.

- BRIGHTWELL . The witness Tool took my boy by mistake, and then let him go, and said the prisoner Charles was the boy - I was with my boy at the time - I had not been five minutes from my master's house - the policeman asked Toole if he was sure - he said he had no doubt of it - I said, "If you go, I will go with you," - and before we got to the London Apprentice, he took the prisoner Charles, and said, "Let the other go, he knows nothing of it."

THOMAS TOOLE re-examined. Q. How can you explain this? A. On the Sunday night, I saw Charles Kelly turn down a little court, and I went back for a policeman - I said to him, "There is a young fellow gone down here that robbed a person of his handkerchief last night" - I described him quite fully - we went down together, and saw this man's boy, and took him - he had a cap on his head, and I thought he was the boy - I brought him out, and a mob came round - the prisoner then came out and I said, "Take him, that is the boy."
NOT GUILTY .

1113.
THOMAS HALLAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 3 silver spoons, value 7s. ; the goods of
Thomas Ayres
.

THOMAS AYRES. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in Bath-street, City-road
. The prisoner was my errand boy for about a fortnight - we missed three spoons, one at a time - part of one was found at a refiner's, and one on the prisoner.

EDWARD ALLISON
. I am apprentice to the prosecutor. He missed three spoons - I accused the prisoner of having one - he denied it; but he pulled this one from his breeches pocket.

JOHN JEFFRYS
. I am a refiner. A boy (who I think was the prisoner) brought a broken spoon to our house, which was placed among other silver - I asked him his mother's name, and he told me a name which corresponded with the name on the spoon.(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 14. - Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury . -
Whipped and Discharged .

1114.
MARY ASHTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 2 gowns, value 5s.: 2 pinafores, value 3s.; 1 pelerine, value 1s.; 6 shells, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 2s.; 1 half-sovereign; and 40 shillings; the goods and monies of
Elizabeth Gull
, her mistress .

JOSEPH WINNEY GULL
. The prisoner was servant to my mother, Elizabeth Gull - she keeps the Duke of Marlborough public-house
- she was with her three months, and my mother gave her warning to leave - on the day she was going, she brought her box (which was locked) down to the ground floor - my mother said it was her custom to search the boxes of her servants, and the prisoner gave her the key - she opened it, and the property was found - the prisoner said she was very sorry, and thought there was no harm in taking these things - the money was not in the box - I told the officer we had better search her person - she resisted very much; but we searched, and found on her 2l. 16s. - she said, "You cannot prove that is yours" - she was then taken to the station-house - she asked me if I would forgive her - I said it was not in my power.

ELIZA SARAH GULL
. I am the prosecutrix's daughter. I was present when the prisoner's trunk was opened, and the property found - we had not missed it, nor the money - she said several times that she did not think there was any harm in taking the things; they are but of small value - my mother never gave them to her.

ELLEN EARLS
. I lived at the prosecutrix's. I saw the prisoner at the closet where the cash box was kept, and heard the money rattle; but I cannot say that she took any - when she went to bed, she told me there were six cakes in her mistress's closet.

(
William Hitchin
, a silk and trimming-manufacturer;
Sarah Smith
; and Mrs. Howard, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 18. - Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix and Jury . -
Confined Three Months .

1115.
JOHN SIMMS
and
THOMAS WOOLBARD WHITTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 bracelet, value 2s., the goods of
Robert Parker
, from the person of
Frederick Parker
.

MARY BILLINGSLEY
. I am nursemaid in the family of Mr. Robert Parker. On the 1st of July, I had the care of his child, Frederick Parker - I was in Kingsland-road
, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon - he had a bracelet on - it was snatched off suddenly - I turned and saw the two prisoners - I called, "Stop thief;" and they ran - I pursued, and the policeman took them just as I came up to them.

GEORGE BONNEY
. I was there, and saw Billingsley with the child - I saw the two prisoners - one of them made a snatch at the bracelet - they ran away, and I pursued them - I did not see the bracelet found.

WILLIAM NORTON
. I was going along the road, at a quarter before five o'clock, and picked up this bracelet in the road the prisoners ran.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN GREEN
(police-constable N 214). I heard the alarm, saw the prisoners, and took them.

SIMMS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

WHITTON -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged .

1116.
JOHN WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of June , 1 bird-cage, value 1s. , the goods of
Frederick Smith Butler
.

JAMES ALLEN
. I know the prosecutor's shop - he is a baker - a bird and cage hung in front of his house on the 2nd of June - I saw the prisoner go and take it as I wasstanding at my father's door - I had not known him before - there was another person with him - the prisoner tied two sticks together and took the cage - he lowered it down, and the other took it - they watched the policeman's back being turned - it was just after four o'clock in the morning.
Prisoner. Q. When I came to you, the night I was taken, what did you say? A. I said I did not know you, but I would see in the morning; and when I saw you in the morning, I was sure it was you.

TIMOTHY TOOMEY
(police-constable H 32). I received information, but could not find the prisoner till the 19th of June, when I met him with these two sticks. I took him to Allen, who said, "I do not know you now," but in the morning he knew him - the bird and cage have not been found.
FREDERICK WILLIAM BUTLER. I had a linnet in a cage, which I have lost.
Prisoner. Q. How high was your bird? A. Over the window, about ten feet from the ground.
Prisoner. Was not that enough to make any body a thief? I was going down the Hackney-road, when I was taken - the Lord above is my protector.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .
